skill.name: linkerd-patterns
skill.description: Implement Linkerd service mesh patterns for lightweight, security-focused service mesh deployments. Use when setting up Linkerd, configuring traffic policies, or implementing zero-trust networking with minimal overhead.
skill.summary: Implement Linkerd service mesh patterns for lightweight, security-focused service mesh deployments. ...
skill.author: wshobson

security_audit.summary: This is a pure documentation skill with no executable code. It contains only markdown templates, YAML configurations, and bash command examples for educational purposes. No scripts, network calls, or file system access beyond its own directory.

content.value_statement: Setting up a service mesh can be complex. This skill provides ready-to-use templates and best practices for Linkerd including automatic mTLS, traffic splits for canary deployments, and zero-trust networking configurations.
actual_capabilities: Generate Linkerd installation commands for Kubernetes clusters
Create ServiceProfile configurations with retries and timeouts
Configure TrafficSplit resources for canary and A/B deployments
Define ServerAuthorization policies for zero-trust networking
Build multi-cluster Linkerd setups across multiple Kubernetes clusters
Provide monitoring commands for Linkerd traffic and metrics
limitations: Does not execute kubectl or linkerd commands directly
Requires manual review of generated YAML before applying to clusters
Does not validate cluster compatibility or resource limits
Cannot interact with running Kubernetes clusters

output_examples.input: How do I enable automatic mTLS with Linkerd?
output: Linkerd enables automatic mTLS by default. The control plane issues certificates to each proxy, and services authenticate using those certificates.
â€¢ Install Linkerd - mTLS is automatic for all injected pods
â€¢ No additional configuration required for basic mTLS
â€¢ Use ServiceProfiles to enable per-route metrics and retries
â€¢ Verify mTLS status: linkerd identity -n <namespace>
Linkerd uses short-lived certificates rotated automatically. All traffic between Linkerd proxies is encrypted and authenticated by default.

best_practices: Enable automatic mTLS for all services - it is on by default and requires no configuration.
Use ServiceProfiles to get per-route metrics and enable retries and timeouts for improved reliability.
Set retry budgets to prevent retry storms when downstream services experience issues.
Run linkerd check after any configuration change to verify the mesh is healthy.
anti_patterns: Skipping the pre-installation check with linkerd check --pre before deploying.
Over-configuring Linkerd - the defaults are production-tested and suitable for most workloads.
Ignoring ServiceProfiles - they unlock advanced features like retries and per-route metrics.
Forgetting to set appropriate timeouts per route, leaving requests vulnerable to hanging.

faq.question: Is Linkerd compatible with my existing Kubernetes cluster?
faq.answer: Linkerd requires Kubernetes 1.21 or later. Run linkerd check --pre to validate cluster compatibility before installation.

faq.question: What is the resource overhead of Linkerd?
faq.answer: Each injected pod runs a lightweight proxy consuming approximately 10-50MB memory and minimal CPU. Control plane uses roughly 1GB memory total.

faq.question: Can I use Linkerd with my existing ingress controller?
faq.answer: Yes, Linkerd works with ingress controllers like NGINX, Traefik, and Istio. Configure the ingress to enable Linkerd injection for traffic management.

faq.question: Does this skill send data to external servers?
faq.answer:: No. This skill is purely documentation-based. It generates YAML configurations and commands that you run in your own environment.

faq.question: Why are my Linkerd proxies not showing traffic metrics?
faq.answer: Ensure ServiceProfiles exist for your services. Metrics require both Linkerd injection and a corresponding ServiceProfile in the same namespace.

faq.question: How does Linkerd compare to Istio for lightweight deployments?
faq.answer: Linkerd has a smaller resource footprint and simpler architecture. It uses Rust for the data plane for security and performance, while Istio offers more features with higher complexity.
